description: Had you ever met a homeless person? Did you decide to help them of not? However, it’s important to help them anyway you could, normal people should, and could help the homeless. but if he don’t needs help, you could leave him alone for some time. There might be someone which could help him! Here’s a story:
title: Should We Reach Out (G4)

description: Equal triangles (ABC, DEF) on equal bases (BC, EF) which form parts of the same right line, and on the same side of the line, are between the same parallels.
title: Euclid Book I PROP. XL. -- THEOREM.

description: Equal triangles (BAC, BDC) on the same base (BC) and on the same side of it are between the same parallels.
title: Euclid Book I PROP. XXXIX. -- THEOREM.

description: Two triangles on the equal bases and between the same parallels are equal.
title: Euclid Book I PROP. XXXVIII. -- THEOREM.

description: Triangles (ABC, DBC) on the same base (BC) and between the same parallels (AD, BC) are equal.
title: Euclid Book I PROP. XXXVII. -- THEOREM.

description: Parallelograms (BD, FH) on equal bases (BC, FG) and between then same parallels are equal.
title: Euclid Book I PROP. XXXVI. -- THEOREM.

description: Parallelograms on the same base (BC) and between the same parallels are equal.
title: Euclid Book I PROP. XXXV. -- THEOREM.

description: The opposite sides (AB, CD,; AC, BD) and the opposite angles (A, D; B, C) of a parallelogram are equal to one another, and either diagonal bisects the parallelogram.
title: Euclid Book I PROP. XXXIV. -- THEOREM.

description: The right lines (AC, BD) which join the adjacent extremities of two equal and parallel right lines (AB, CD) are equal and parallel.
title: Euclid Book I PROP. XXXIII. -- THEOREM.

description: If any side (AB) of a triangle (ABC) be produced (to D), the external angle (CBD) is equal to the sum of the two internal non-adjacent angles (A, C), and the sum of the three internal angles is equal to two right angles.
title: Euclid Book I PROP. XXXII. -- THEOREM.

description: Through a given point (C) to draw a right line parallel to a given right line.
title: Euclid Book I PROP. XXXI. -- PROBLEM.

description: If two right lines (AB, CD) be parallel to the same right line (EF), they are parallel to one another.
title: Euclid Book I PROP. XXX. -- THEOREM.

description:
If a right line (EF) intersect two parallel right lines (AB, CD), it makes:

  1. the alternate angles (AGH, GHD) equal to one another;
  2. the exterior angle (EGB) equal to the corresponding interior angle (GHD);
  3. the two interior angles (BGH, GHD) on the same side equal to two right angles.
title: Euclid Book I PROP. XXIX. -- THEOREM.

description: If a right line (EF) intersect two parallel right lines (AB, CD) makes the exterior angle (EGB) equal to its corresponding interior angle (GHD), or makes two interior angles (BGH, GHD) on the same side equal to two right angles, the two right lines are parallel.
title: Euclid Book I PROP. XXVIII. -- THEOREM.

description: If a right line (EF) intersecting two right lines (AB, CD) makes the alternate angles (AEF, EFD) equal to each other, these lines are parallel.
title: Euclid Book I PROP. XXVII. -- THEOREM.

description: If two triangles (ABC, DEF) have two angles B, C) of one equal respectively to two angles (E, F) of the other, and a side of one equal to a side similarly placed with respect to the equal angles of the other, the triangles are equal in every respect.
title: Euclid Book I PROP. XXVI. -- THEOREM.

description: If two triangles (ABC, DEF) have two sides (AB, AC) of one respectively equal to two sides (DE, DF) of the other, but the base (BC) of one greater than the base (EF) of the other, the angle (A) contained by the sides of that which has the greater base is greater them the angle (D) contained by the sides of the other.
title: Euclid Book I PROP. XXV. -- THEOREM.

description: If two triangles (ABC, DEF) have two sides (AB, AC) of one respectively equal to two sides (DE, DF) of the other, but the contained angle (BAC) of one greater than the contained angle (EDF) of the other, the base of that which has the greater angle is greater than the base of the other.
title: Euclid Book I PROP. XXIV. -- THEOREM.

description: At a given point (A) in a given right line (AB) to make an angle equal to a given rectilineal angle (DEF)
title: Euclid Book I PROP. XXIII. -- PROBLEM.

description: To construct a triangle which three sides shall be respectively equal to three given lines (A, B, C), the sum of every two of which is greater than the third.
title: Euclid Book I PROP. XXII. -- PROBLEM.

description: If two lines (BD, CD) be drawn to a point (D) within a triangle from the extremities of its base (BD), their sum is less than the sum of the remaining sides (BA, CA), but they contain a greater angle.
title: Euclid Book I PROP. XXI. -- THEOREM.

description: The sum of any two sides (BA, AC) of a triangle (ABC) is greater than the third.
title: Euclid Book I PROP. XX. -- THEOREM.

description: If one angle (B) of a triangle (ABC) be greater than another angle (C), the side (AC) which it opposite to the greater angle is greater than the side (AB) which is opposite to the less.
title: Euclid Book I PROP. XIX. -- THEOREM.

description: If in any triangle (ABC) one side (AC) be greater than another (AB), the angle opposite to the greater side is greater than the angle opposite to the less.
title: Euclid Book I PROP. XVIII. -- THEOREM.

description: Any two angles (B, C) of a triangle (ABC) are together less than two right angles.
title: Euclid Book I PROP. XVII. -- THEOREM.

description: If any side (BC) of a triangle (ABC) be produced, the exterior angle (ACD) is greater than either of the interior non-adjacent angles.
title: Euclid Book I PROP. XVI. -- THEOREM.

description: If Two right lines (AB, CD) intersect one another, the opposite angles are equal (CEA=DEB, and BEC=AED)
title: Euclid Book I PROP. XV. -- THEOREM.

description: If at a point (B) in a right line (BA) two other right lines (CB, BD) on opposite sides make the adjacent angles (CBA, ABD) together equal to two right angles, these two right lines form one continuous line.
title: Euclid Book I PROP. XIV. -- THEOREM.

description: The adjacent angles (ABC, ABD) which one right lines (AB) standing on another (CD) makes with it are either both right angles, or their sum is equal to two right angles.
title: Euclid Book I PROP. XIII. -- THEOREM.

description: To draw a perpendicular to a given indefinite right line (AB) from a given point (C) without it.
title: Euclid Book I PROP. XII. -- PROBLEM.

description: From a given point (C) in a given right line (AB) to draw a right line perpendicular to the given line.
title: Euclid Book I PROP. XI. -- PROBLEM.

description: To bisect a given finite right line (AB).
title: Euclid Book I PROP. X. -- PROBLEM.

description: To bisect a given rectilineal angle (BAC).
title: Euclid Book I PROP. IX. -- PROBLEM.

description: If two triangles (ABC, DEF) have two sides (AB, AC) of one respectively equal to two sides…
title: Euclid Book I PROP. VIII. -- THEOREM.

description: If two triangles (ACB, ADB) on the same base (AB) and on the same side of it have one …
title: Euclid Book I PROP. VII. -- THEOREM.

description: If two angles (B, C) of a triangle be equal, the sides (AC, AB) opposite to them are also equal.
title: Euclid Book I PROP. VI. – THEOREM.

description: The angles (ABC, ACB) at the base (BC) of an isosceles triangle are equal to one another…
title: Euclid Book I PROP. V. – THEOREM.

description: If two triangle (BAC, EDF) have two sides (BA, AC) of one equal respectively to two sides…
title: Euclid Book I PROP. IV. – THEOREM.

description: From the greater (AB) of two given right lines to cut off a part equal to (C) the less.
title: Euclid Book I PROP. III. – PROBLEM.

description: From a given point (A) to draw a right line equal to a given finite right line (BC).
title: Euclid Book I PROP. II. – PROBLEM.

description: On a given finite right line (AB) to construct an equilateral triangl.
title: Euclid Book I PROP. I. – PROBLEM.
